I am am a baker of South Lambeth Road—on 15th March, about 4.30, my wife served the prisoner with two halfpenny biscuits—he put down 1s.—she gave him the change—I looked at the coin before he left, and saw that it was bad—I went after him, stopped him, and told him he had given me a bad shilling—he said, "I was not aware of it. Some man gave it to me to come and get some biscuits"—I said, "You had better come back to the shop with me"—he called to some man who was walking across to the other side of the road, but he took no notice—I took the prisoner back to the shop, and while waiting for a constable he took the seidlitz-powder out of his pocket, and began to tear off the label—I gave him in charge with the coin.
Cross-examined. I did not see a man running away—you offered me all the money yon had, and said that you would call and pay the rest.

SAMUEL HUBBARD . (Policeman W 310). I was fetched to Mr. Read's shop, and he gave the prisoner in custody for giving him a bad shilling—I searched him, and found on him sixpence in silver, three halfpence, and this seidlitz-powder—I saw the name of Bate on the label, and I went there with Mr. Read—I produce the two shillings I received from Mr. Read and Mr. Bate—I asked the prisoner his address—he refused to give any.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These coins are both bad—not from the same mould.

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence stated that he received the coins and seidlitz-powder from another man.

div1.p:
GUILTY —
Nine Months' Imprisonment.

426.
PETER SMART (23) was indicted
for a like offence.

CHARLES THOMPSON . I keep the Phoenix public-house, Stacey Street, Soho; on 17th February, about 7.40 p.m., I served the prisoner with a pint of four ale, which came to twopence; he tendered a half-crown,

which I noticed was base at once—I said, "Are you aware this is bad, Charley?"—he said, "I was not aware of it, sir; I never did a thing like it Wore; if you like you can take off my boots and stockings and search me"—I said, "How did you come by it?"—he said, "I think I got it at Billingsgate Market this morning"—I detained him and sent for a constable, and gave the half-crown to him—the prisoner was charged next day at Marlborough Street, remanded, and then dis
charged, there being no further evidence against him—this is the half-crown—I had not known him before, though—I called him Charlie.
DANIEL REDMOND (Policeman E 159). I was called to the Phoenix, and received the prisoner in custody with this half-crown.

GEORGE BURTON (Policeman L 81). On the evening of 1st March, about 9.15, I was with Constable Baker in Newington Butts, and saw the prisoner with another man—they were shortly joined by a third, and they went towards Kennington Park—they stopped outside Mr. Fossi's ice-shop—I lost sight of the prisoner there—the other two went across the road and stood against the park railings in the dark—they all three joined again, and the prisoner went into Mr. Wilson's, came out, and went into Church Street, the other two following him—I sent Baker in to Mr. Wilson's—when he came out they saw us and ran off—I caught the prisoner and said, "I shall take you in charge for uttering a counter
feit florin"—he said, "I was just coming from Clapham when two men asked me if my name was Peter Smart, and if I would have a pint of beer; they gave me the money; I did not know it was bad; I did not know the men; they sent me in"—he afterwards said, "I only knew them by sight"—I afterwards received a florin from Mr. Fossi.

GEORGE BAKER (Policeman L 244). I was with the last witness—I went into the tobacconist's shop and spoke to Mr. Wilson—I saw the prisoners and the two others standing under a lamp in Church Street—I afterwards made a search there and found the bad florin and a penny.

FARINO FOSSI . I keep an ice shop at 244, Kennington Park Road—about 9.30 on the evening of 18th March a young man, who I could not swear to, paid me this florin—I gave him 1s. 9d. change—about an hour after the police came, and I looked in the till and found that the florin was bad—there was no other florin there—I gave it to the constable.

THOMAS WILSON . I am manager to Mrs. Moxon, of 328, Kennington Park Road, tobacconist—on 1st March, about 9.45, the prisoner came for half an ounce of tobacco and tendered a florin—I told him it was bad—he wanted me to hand it back to him, which I did after breaking it in the detector—he said he was not aware it was bad, and tendered a penny, which he said was all the money he had besides the florin—very soon after Baker came in.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . This half-crown is bad; the two florins are also bad, and from the same mould.

GUILTY .—
Nine Month' Imprisonment.

427.
DAVID THOMAS DAVIES (21)
, Feloniously wounding
Catherine Davies, with intent to murder her. Second Count, with intent to do grievous bodily harm.
MESSRS. POLAND and MONTAGU WILLIAMS Prosecuted; MR. LILLEY Defended.

CATHERINE DAVIES . I am the prisoner's wife, and live at 55, Gravel Lane, Southwark—we keep a general shop—on the 13th December, a little after twelve at night, my husband was putting up the shutters—there were some boxes in the way—he asked me to remove them, which I refused to do—he did nothing to me; it was my fault entirely—he moved the boxes himself, and came to me in a passion, and I flew at him and struck him in the face with my fist—he did not strike me back—we were scuffling together, and both of us fell by the door leading to the shop, and I felt that I was stabbed, but how I can't say—I did not see any knife—I said I was stabbed—he said I was not, for he never touched the knife—we were by the door between the shop and the parlour, at the top of the steps—there was a large knife kept on a slab just by the door for cutting the bacon—I was wounded in the stomach, on the left side—the knife penetrated all my clothes; I was dressed as usual—I suppose a doctor was sent for; I hardly remember anything after that—the doctor attended me at home, I dare say over two months, but not so frequently lately—I was told that I was likely to die, and I made a statement, as well as I could, in the presence of my husband and the inspector.

Cross-examined. We had been married three years, and lived very comfortably together—my husband has never struck me; he was a good husband and good to my child—he had been out on this night and might have had a little drink—I was in a great passion and hardly knew what I did; I believe I did say "You have been out whore
mongering again"—in the scuffle our clothes might have touched the slab on which the knife was, it projects a little over the steps—in the scuffle I tore the lappel of his coat and scratched his face—I might have scratched his wrist with my nails.

By the COURT. He was not in the habit of drinking—we had been the best of friends during the morning; there had been nothing to put me out, only I thought he was rather bad tempered, and I thought I would be the same—I don't know why I used that offensive expression to him—I was in such a dreadful rage and bad temper I hardly knew what I said.

HANNAH BEVINS . I am unmarried, and now live at 85, Chatham Street, Walworth; I formerly lived at 55, Gravel Lane—on the night of the 13th December about 12.20 I saw the prisoner putting up the shutters—I went away and returned in about 10 minutes; I then found the shop closed—I heard Mrs. Davies scream "help and murder" and heard some one fall—I unlocked the door and went in, and saw her lying on the ground in the passage near the parlour door; the prisoner was leaning over her—she said "I am stabbed"—I asked him if he had done it; he said "No"—she was lifted into the parlour into a chair by Mr. Fotherby—I didn't see any knife about; there were no supper things on the table—they occupied the shop and two parlours at the back.

Cross-examined. When I first went in the prisoner seemed to be assist
ing her—I had lodged there about three months; during that time they seemed to live comfortably together.

MARY ANN FOTHERBY . I am the wife of Charles Daniel Fotherby—on 13th December I was living at 55, Gravel Lane; we occupied the first floor front room—I have known the prisoner and his wife some time; he generally went out to work in the daytime and Mrs. Daviea attended to

the shop—about 12.30 on this night I was in bed; I heard the shop closed and the shutters being put up—about five or six minutes after that I heard Mrs. Davies scream out help and murder—my husband got up and ran downstairs; he called me, and I went down and found Mrs. Davies in the arm-chair in the parlour and the prisoner standing by her—she said "Undress me; let the gentlemen go out of the room and I will show you"—they went out and I pulled her clothes aside, and saw that she was stabbed on the left side of the lower part of the stomach—I said to the prisoner, "Mr. Davies, have you stabbed her?" he said "No"—she said "You liar, you have"—my husband went for the doctor—the prisoner tried to get some brandy for his wife, and I went upstairs to get a sofa for her—I saw no knife anywhere—the furniture in the parlour was all straight except one chair; that was right over in a corner of the room.
Cross-examined. They were in the house about two months while I was there, as far as I know they lived comfortably together—I heard some scuffling before I went down.

CHARLES DANIEL FOTHERBY . I live at 55, Gravel Lane—on 13th December about 12.20 I heard a little bit of scuffling downstairs in the parlour underneath—I got out of bed and listened, and after two or three minutes I heard "murder and help" screamed—I ran downstairs and saw Mrs. Davies lying in the passage, and the prisoner close to her—I pulled her up and put her on a chair, she said she was stabbed—I said, "Where?" she said, "Here, but I can't tell you"—I said, "If you are stabbed, where is the knife?"—I looked about but could not see one—the prisoner said he had done nothing—I went for the doctor.

Cross-examined. I have known the prisoner some time—as far as I know he has always behaved in a proper manner—I have not spoken to him above three or four times—he was very drunk on this night, and did not know what he was doing; he was like mad with drink, and when he saw what he had done he turned all manner of colours.

CHARLES GRAHAM (Police Inspector M). On the morning of the 14th a little after 2 I went to 55, Gravel Lane—I saw the prisoner in the passage—I asked if he was the landlord, he said, "Yes"—we went into the back parlour—I found Mrs. Davies there, and Dr. Wilson and his assistant—I asked Mrs. Davies who had committed the assault upon her, she replied, "My husband"—he made no reply at that time—in conse
quence of what the doctor said I thought it right to take a statement from her—the prisoner was present—it was made in answer to ques
tions that I and Dr. Wilson put to her—I took it down and read it over to her, and she put her mark to it: this is it. (Read: "I believe I am in a dying state, and make the following statement voluntarily. My husband and I have not for the last two days been on good terms. He has been drinking. He struck me first with his fist. I defended myself as well as I could. He had then no knife in his hand when he was putting up the shutters. He found some wooden boxes in his way. He got angry at this, and struck me with the shop knife. When I received the blow I rushed to the door and screamed 'Murder.' Mrs. Fotherby came. I showed the wound to her. I am positive my husband done it; there was no other person in the room. I don't know the cause of the quarrel. I was perfectly sober. I had had a portion of a quartern of gin between four of us, one of whom was my husband's mother.") When she had made

this statement I sent the prisoner to the station, and then searched the house—I found these two knives (produced)—this long thin one was on the counter in the shop, about eight feet from the parlour door—this broad one was on the bacon-slab beside the door, a few inches from it—the thin knife was clean, the other had a stain on the point of it—I could not see what the stain was, it was dry—I called Dr. Wilson's attention to it—I hare the clothes which the prosecutrix was wearing—the doctor and I compared the holes in these clothes with the broad knife; the hole went through the apron, dress, and petticoats—the knives were shown to Mrs. Davies, who said she could not identify either of them as the knife with which she was stabbed—I read over the charge to the prisoner at the station; he wanted to make a statement—I cautioned him, and said I would take it down; it might be used against him in evidence—he said, "Very well"—he then made this statement. (Read: "As soon as I. came, home my wife accused me of being out whoremongering again, which I denied, and then started putting up the shutters. There were some cheese-boxes in my way, which annoyed me. I told her to move the things out of the way, when she said, 'B—them; move them yourself'. I then made a rush at her, and attempted to strike her. We went into the parlour and had a free fight. In the scuffle she took up the knife and drawded it across my wrist, which was marked longways. She got the knife from the bacon-board in the shop. In the struggle she got her stab.") I read it over to him and he signed it—I looked at his wrist, and noticed that there was a mark on it—I believe it was the left wrist—it appeared to be a mark from finger-nails, a scratch—it was fresh, but not bleeding then—I called Dr. Wilson's attention to it next day—the prisoner also had some scratches on his right cheek, apparently made with a finger-nail; they were fresh.

Cross-examined. I found the knife on the bacon slab—there are two steps leading from the parlour to the shop—I found the prosecutrix in the sleeping-room; the prisoner was about speaking while we were questioning her, and he was stopped by Dr. Wilson—he said "Hush"—he thought the woman was dying—this dress is a sort of black stuff, the petticoat of flannel; there were no stays—the wound on the prisoner's wrist was about six inches long, extending from the wrist up the arm—I found some dinner knives in a drawer in the parlour; none of those were pointed.

JAMES VANCE YOUNG . I am assistant to Dr. Wilson—I was called by Fotherby to see Mrs. Davies—I arrived about 1.10—I found a wound about four inches above the left groin, with the bowels protruding; I sent for Dr. Wilson.

HENRY WILSON , M.R.C.S. I live at 38, Great Charlotte Street—on the morning of 14th December, shortly after I o'clock, I went to Mrs. Davies—I found her suffering from a punctured wound low down on the left side of the abdomen, the abdominal wall was perforated, and the intestines protruded about a foot and a half; one portion of the intestine was divided in about half its circumference—we removed her to her bed in the adjoining room—I had to enlarge the wound in order to return the intestine, and I then sewed up the external wound; the operation took some considerable time—afterwards, while the woman's statement was being made, the prisoner kept interrupting—I told him for his own sake not to speak—the long knife was brought to me; the woman said

she did not know that it was done with that knife; in my opinion it was probably done with this broad knife—the woman was in great danger at the time—I have attended her ever since; every day for about six weeks, and at intervals since—I think she has quite recovered now—I have seen the clothes (produced)—the holes in them exactly correspond with the larger knife—the clothes would scarcely offer any resistance—I examined the prisoner's wrist the following day—I could not positively say how the wound was caused; probably by a scratch; it might have been from the point of a knife.

Cross-examined. He was very excited—he was not in a fit state to speak—he appeared to be excited by drink—I told him he should speak afterwards if he wished to do so—he kept contradicting each statement that his wife made, and as she was supposed to be in a dying state it caused great confusion—there was only one wound—I did not pay any attention to the knives till the next day—there were some rusty red marks upon it, and some bacon grease—I did not examine it under the microscope.

HENRY HEANEY . (Police Sergeant M 17). I took the prisoner into custody—his coat was torn down at the lappel—he said, "This is the way she treats me; look at my coat"—I saw two scratches on his right cheek—I did not notice the mark on his wrist—he said nothing about it.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p:
GUILTY
of Unlawfully Wounding —
Fifteen Months' Imprisonment.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, MAY 2ND, 1881.
